conclusion: Take the instant when ball A is at the highest point of its circular motion as the observation moment.
Let the angular speed of the system about the shaft be ω at this instant.
Distances from the shaft: rA = L, rB = 2L.
At the highest point ball A is 'just loose', i.e. the rod exerts no force on it (the given condition).
The only forces on A are gravity (mg, downward) and the required centripetal force m rA ω² (toward the shaft, i.e. downward at this instant).
Therefore m rA ω² = m g ⟹ ω² = g / L.
For ball B the forces are its weight mg (downward) and the force F exerted by the rod on B (along the rod, toward O, i.e. upward in the figure).
Required centripetal force toward the shaft: m rB ω² = m (2 L)(g / L) = 2 m g.
Radial (along rod) force balance for B (upward positive toward the shaft): F − m g = m rB ω².
By Newton’s third law, the force ball B exerts on the rod has the same magnitude, opposite direction to F in the above equation.
Hence the force exerted by ball B on the rod (directed away from O, i.e. downward along the rod) is F_B on rod = 3 m g.
Ball B pulls on the rod with a force of 3 m g (directed outward, away from the shaft) when ball A is at the highest point of its motion.
